title: Has Elizabeth Warren Wrecked the Left?
summary: The Warren Medicare for All plan shows that progressivism is undeliverable pie in the sky.. The fallout from the release of Sen. Elizabeth Warren's Medicare for All plan is the biggest event so far in the 2020 presidential campaign. It's big enough that Sen. Warren's campaign may have buckled beneath the weight of her plan's fantastic details. But it might be bigger than that. The Warren meltdown could prove to be the Democratic left's Chernobyl, a lasting catastrophe.

title: When I Faced Adam Schiff
summary: A 2008 Judiciary Committee hearing was heavy on drama, short on substance.. Rep. Adam Schiff recently revealed that, before he entered politics, he wanted to be a screenwriter. He even penned scripts for a courtroom drama and an action-filled spy thriller. Mr. Schiff, now leading the Democratic push to impeach President Trump, hasn't lost his theatrical flair.

title: Parallel Lives of Donald Trump
summary: If Plutarch studied American presidents, to which would he compare and contrast the 45th?. Harry S. Truman kept a set of Plutarch's writings at hand in the White House. title: WarrenCare Will Make You Wait and Wait
summary: Her plan proposes 'global budgets' to control costs. That will inevitably lead to rationing of needed services.. Until now, Medicare for All proposals have been pleasantly vague. They plausibly allowed voters to imagine that more medical services would be covered, without premiums, out-of-pocket costs or the inconvenience of networks or claims reviews by insurers.

title: Don't Take Walking for Granted
summary: Even DiMaggio had discs in his back that shriveled in old age.. As I gaze on the busy world from my wheelchair, I tend to notice the way people walk. My father, who was nearly bald, noticed men with a full head of hair. My envy is not that many walk easily and sturdily, as I did after recovering from a fall in college that left me partly paralyzed, but rather that they can take walking for granted, as I did before aging took a tight grip of me.

title: 'The Great Reversal' Review: When Bigger Is Not Better
summary: Competition has declined in most sectors of the American economy. Where to look for a truly competitive environment? Europe, of all places.. 'The idea that US markets are the most competitive in the world has been widely accepted in economics for several decades," economist Thomas Philippon writes in "The Great Reversal." The thrust of his argument is that this idea is largely a myth. Even before the financial crash of 2007-08, he says, many Americans felt that there was something not right about the economy-that it wasn't performing as advertised. Still, it is routinely assumed that America is a dynamic, wealth-creating powerhouse compared with its sluggish European rivals, burdened as they are by statist oversight and intervention. What few realize, Mr. Philippon says, is that Europe is fast becoming a haven for free-market competition; it's the U.S. that has become mired in an anti-competitive, quasi-monopolistic environment where companies that are "too big to fail" wield influence to crowd out newcomers and drive prices up while pushing investment and productivity down.

title: Richard Feynman on Good, Honest Science and Bad
summary: Andy Kessler's excellent "Follow Michael Crichton's Rule" on the dumbing down of "science, the data and the studies" brings to mind the great Nobel physicist Richard Feynman's 1974 Caltech commencement address entitled "Cargo Cult Science.". Andy Kessler's excellent "Follow Michael Crichton's Rule" (Inside View, Nov. 4) on the dumbing down of "science, the data and the studies" brings to mind the great Nobel physicist Richard Feynman's 1974 Caltech commencement address entitled "Cargo Cult Science." Feynman's instructive words to the students (many of them future scientists) echoes strongly today: "For example, if you're doing an experiment, you should report everything that you think might make it invalid-not only what you think is right about it: other causes that could possibly explain your results; and things you thought of that you've eliminated by some other experiment, and how they worked-to make sure the other fellow can tell they've been eliminated. Details that could throw doubt on your interpretation must be given, if you know them. You must do the best you can-if you know anything at all wrong, or possibly wrong-to explain it. . . . In summary, the idea is to give all of the information to help others to judge the value of your contribution [theory]; not just the information that leads to judgment in one particular direction or another."

title: Rep. Katie Hill Should Take Responsibility for Her Acts
summary: Do we need another Democrat bellyaching about victimhood?. WASHINGTON-The wealth taxes proposed by top Democratic presidential candidates might spark a short-term boom in billionaires' donations to charity, as they accelerate gifts to avoid years of taxes eroding their fortunes.

title: If Warren Scraps Private Health Care, Beware Unintended Consequences
summary: Presidential candidate's promise that Medicare for All will deliver more care for less money needs a reality check. At the heart of presidential candidate Sen. Elizabeth Warren's ambitious Medicare for All plan is this tantalizing promise: the U.S. can spend less on health care than it does now yet get a lot more for it: 32 million people currently uninsured will have coverage, while copays and deductibles will disappear and everyone will get long-term care.

title: Airbus to Expand Production in China, Putting Further Pressure on Boeing
summary: European plane maker's move comes as U.S. rival grapples with trade tensions, MAX grounding. Airbus SE plans to boost jetliner production in China, bolstering its position in what is set to be the world's biggest aviation market and piling further pressure on Boeing Co. as the U.S. company contends with trade tensions and the grounding of its 737 MAX plane.

title: Six Luminaries on the Meaning of Convention
summary: Etiquette expert Lizzie Post, director Rian Johnson and more weigh in on this month's Columnists topic: convention. "My first job in journalism was at an alt-weekly, which was like working for an internet startup. I was absolutely anti-convention. Later, I worked for a magazine called Washington Monthly. We found it very exciting that the economy was being deregulated. We didn't use the word disruption, but we definitely thought existing institutional structures were stifling. A better world would emerge if they were taken away. The result was a world that I don't find as appealing as I thought it would be. Most people live regular day-to-day lives and don't find the idea of disruption all that compelling. Often, that kind of rhetoric has accompanied breaking things apart. When the smoke clears, inequality has increased, and elites have benefited more than ordinary people. The reason conventions exist is they stood the test of time. To improve on them, the odds against you are really long."

title: Chef Daniel Humm's Return to London-And On His Own
summary: Eleven Madison Park's chef Daniel Humm, whose breakup earlier this year with partner Will Guidara rocked the food world, launches his first solo venture-at the London hotel where he used to peel tomatoes. The first time Daniel Humm moved to London, in 1992, he didn't have a job. A 16-year-old high school dropout, Humm was training to become a professional mountain-bike racer in his native Switzerland when he decided to follow his then-girlfriend, Elaine Mathieu, to London for the off-season. Having completed a stint in the kitchen at Zurich's renowned Baur au Lac hotel, Humm began looking for work as a cook. He circulated his résumé among London's grandest hotels, including The Dorchester, The Savoy and Claridge's, the stately Mayfair address that has lodged royals, dignitaries and celebrities since the mid-19th century.

title: Snakeskin Bags: The Key for Day-to-Night Dressing
summary: Six elegant bags in crocodile, python and iguana add an exotic touch to any outfit. A classic black bag gets a reptilian update. Dolce & Gabbana, price upon request, select Dolce & Gabbana stores

title: Impeachment Transcripts Reveal Partisan Tensions, Bipartisan Complaints
summary: Cramped quarters in secure facility make for 'locker room' stuffiness amid questioning of witnesses. WASHINGTON-Inside the basement room where impeachment investigators have deposed roughly a dozen witnesses, the climate alternates between freezing and stuffy. It is too crowded for everyone to get a seat. Lawmakers have become cautious about bringing food because the odors get trapped in the windowless secure facility.

title: How Julianne Moore Is Fighting for Safer Kids
summary: Academy Award-winning actress Julianne Moore has inhabited an inimitable range of characters, appearing in 70-plus films. Beyond Hollywood, Moore has also channeled her voice into one of her most notable roles yet: activist. Do I need to persuade you on Julianne Moore? Come on. This is Julianne Moore we're talking about. The intensely credible, never-bad-in-anything actress with a career that now spans almost four decades and includes work with Robert Altman; Louis Malle; the Coen Brothers; Alfonso Cuarón; Todd Haynes; Kimberly Peirce; Tom Ford; Paul Thomas Anderson; Rebecca Miller; Julie Taymor; Moore's husband, Bart Freundlich; and probably 38 other really good directors I'm forgetting. The Julianne Moore who's been nominated for five Academy Awards, winning best actress in 2015 for playing a professor confronting Alzheimer's disease in Still Alice. The Julianne Moore who won an Emmy for playing-no, transforming into-Sarah Palin in Game Change. Who played Maude flippin' Lebowski, for crying out loud. "She's just a lovely person," says The Dude himself, Moore's co-star in The Big Lebowski, Jeff Bridges. Bridges calls her Julie, just as many close to her do.

title: Ohio State, LSU Top College Football Playoff Rankings
summary: First rankings by selection committee set up two matchups against top four-ranked teams. The world got its first look at which teams might appear in the College Football Playoff Semifinal on Tuesday when the playoff selection committee released the first edition of its all-important rankings. If the season were to end this week, No. 1 Ohio State would play against No. 4 Penn State and No. 2 LSU would face No. 3 Alabama.

title: Scandal? College Basketball Begins With a Bang
summary: No. 4 Duke edged No. 3 Kansas, while No. 2 Kentucky topped No. 1 Michigan State in a high-powered doubleheader after two years of unease roiled the sport. The college basketball season began in the tastiest way possible with the country's top-four teams-Michigan State, Kentucky, Kansas and Duke-playing in two games at Madison Square Garden.

title: Adidas Is More Balanced but Still Lagging
summary: Nike's main rival is growing sales more evenly across regions than before. Stopping market share losses is the next challenge. Adidas's task is to keep pace with rivals and investors' high expectations alike.

title: After WeWork, SoftBank Needs to Soften Its Ambitions
summary: SoftBank says it is still planning another $100 billion venture capital fund, but shareholders want the company to slow down. A chief executive likely knows he has gone too far when he is asked if the company has any control process to make sure he doesn't go crazy. SoftBank Chairman Masayoshi Son, who took that question from a reporter during the company's earnings briefing Wednesday, needs to do more to convince his investors.

title: A New Strain of HIV Is Recorded Under Group That Caused Pandemic
summary: Latest strain was found in just three people. Scientists using advanced DNA sequencing technology have documented a previously unidentified strain of HIV under the group that is responsible for the vast majority of human infections.

title: Huawei Founder Says Chinese Giant Doesn't Need the U.S.
summary: 'The China-U.S. trade talks are not something I'm concerned with,' Ren Zhengfei declared. SHENZHEN-Huawei Technologies Co. can survive without the U.S., Chief Executive Ren Zhengfei said, dismissing Washington's campaign against it as ineffective.

title: CVS Beats Revenue Expectations
summary: Company now expects adjusted profit between $6.97 and $7.05 a share for the year. CVS Health Corp. reported a stronger-than-expected adjusted profit in the third quarter and raised its outlook for earnings.

title: Adidas Boosts Sales as Sneaker Race With Nike Steps Up
summary: Demand for Adidas' Superstar and Stan Smith fashion shoes has cooled and its Boost performance-running line is more than six years old. BERLIN-Adidas AG is growing sales around the world and has rebounded from supply-chain challenges and stumbles in its home market. But Nike Inc.'s rising dominance in shoe technology could put the German sportswear maker on the back foot.

title: Russia Targets Dissenters-Right in Their Bank Accounts
summary: Activists say hundreds of people suddenly found themselves $1.2 million in debt, the amount Moscow alleges opposition group laundered for crime lords. MOSCOW-One morning in September, Andrei Yegorov woke to discover his bank account was frozen and in the red to the tune of 75 million rubles, almost $1.2 million.

title: Hairdresser, Plumber, Lawyer: A Job License Could Help You Get a Loan
summary: Consumers who hold any of about 5,000 professional licenses could get a boost. A new credit score will soon factor in consumers' rent payments and professional licenses to help them get approved for loans.

title: The Bahamas for the Holidays? This Year's the Year
summary: Hurricane Dorian hit the island nation hard, but many of the islands and resorts were spared. With crowds on the light side, now's the time to start planning. WHEN HURRICANE Dorian battered the Bahamas this past September, it was the worst storm to hit the country in recorded history. Fortunately, the storm's destruction was limited to a handful of islands; the Abacos, for instance, might take years to recover. But even Grand Bahama, the second-worst hit, has reopened its cruise port and will resume international flights this month. With crowds smaller than usual, it's arguably a good time to visit and the islands need support.

title: South Korea Is Having Fewer Babies; Soon It Will Have Fewer Soldiers
summary: A declining birthrate means the military is expected to shrink by about 100,000 people by 2022. SEOUL-South Korea's declining birthrate has become a national-security challenge: Fewer young men are around for military service.

title: China's Smog Gauge Is Signaling Trouble
summary: Lower pollution levels are the latest sign that the construction sector in the world's second-largest economy is weakening. There is a running joke in Beijing that if you want to know how the Chinese economy is doing, just look out of your window. The thicker the smog, the better things are.

title: BMW Earnings Bounce Back but Industry Woes Remain
summary: Slower growth, lower profit over the year as industry outlook softens. BERLIN- BMW AG returned to profit in the third quarter, helped by cost-cutting and a sales shift to higher-margin sport-utility vehicles, but it warned that Germany's luxury car industry would continue to be squeezed by growing costs and heightened competition.

title: Saudis to Press OPEC Members for Production Cuts Ahead of Aramco IPO
summary: Kingdom wants cartel's laggards to comply with current curbs, rather than pushing for deeper trims in output.

title: Stocks to Watch: HP, Match, WW International and Others
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Wednesday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours.

title: McKinsey Employees Give to Alum and Critic Buttigieg
summary: Candidate has distanced himself from some of the big consulting firm's work. Pete Buttigieg has recently distanced himself from the consulting powerhouse that represents the main private-sector job on his résumé, but he is the biggest beneficiary in the 2020 Democratic presidential primary of donations from McKinsey & Co. employees.

title: More Women Pursue M.B.A. as Elite Schools Step Up Recruiting
summary: As total applications decline, percentage of female students rises for many top programs. As applications to American business schools decline, the percentage of women enrolled in full-time M.B.A. programs continues to rise, climbing this fall to an average of 39% at more than 50 of the top programs in the U.S., Canada and Europe, new data show.

title: China, 5G Uncertainty Cloud Qualcomm's Outlook
summary: The chip maker will post its latest report following a muted revenue forecast. Mobile-phone chip giant Qualcomm Inc. is expected to report fiscal fourth-quarter earnings after the market closes Wednesday. The results come after the company previously issued a muted sales forecast amid uncertainty over how long it will take the latest mobile communications technology to take root. Here is what to expect:

title: Lessons From the Office Travel Guru
summary: Everyone knows that veteran flier who knows all the shortcuts to better, cheaper trips; for all the questions, many of them secretly love giving the advice. Some co-workers know all the hottest new restaurants for people in search of a special meal. Others pitch in with clever budgeting workarounds. But when you're the office oracle for travel, your advice is in constant demand.

title: When Admissions Adviser Rick Singer Called, This School Said, 'No, Thanks'
summary: Years ago, Occidental College opted not to use admissions to chase money. The decision came with a cost.. One day in 2012, an admissions director at Occidental College got a surprising email. William "Rick" Singer proposed that the school reconsider an application from an academically challenged daughter of a wealthy family.

title: Gunmen in Southern Thailand Kill Security Officers at Checkpoints
summary: A separatist insurgency in the region has left about 7,000 people dead since 2004. HATYAI, Thailand-Gunmen fired at security personnel at checkpoints in Thailand's insurgency-wracked south, killing 15 volunteer officers and wounding five others, police said Wednesday.

title: China's Uber Rival Restarts Carpool Service Halted After Passenger Deaths
summary: Didi had suspended the "Hitch" service after two female passengers were killed by their drivers last year.. BEIJING-Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing Technology Co. is resuming its "Hitch" carpool service, which it halted in 2018 after two female passengers were killed by drivers in the space of a few months, the company said Wednesday.

title: New York City Re-Elects Williams as Public Advocate in Polls
summary: Melinda Katz wins Queens district attorney race. Jumaane Williams was re-elected New York City public advocate on Tuesday, easily beating his opponent who had campaigned on a pledge to get rid of the seat if he won.

title: Dow Industrials Rise on Hopes for Trade Deal
summary: U.S. and China have agreed in principle to initial trade deal; Uber shares fall. The Dow Jones Industrial Average edged higher Tuesday as investors grew hopeful that the U.S. and China will roll back tariffs as they work to clinch a partial trade deal.

title: The Trillion-Dollar Math of Aramco's IPO Doesn't Add Up
summary: Aramco is the world's most profitable company, but whatever the valuation, it might fail to take account of Saudi Arabia's political risk. Is Saudi Arabia's oil monopoly more like Exxon Mobil or a dodgy government bond? Valuing Saudi Aramco ahead of its planned initial public offering produces an unusually large range between $1 trillion and more than $2 trillion depending on what investors think they are buying. Maybe it is worth even less than that.

title: U.S. Presses Mexico to Take On Cartels After Killings of U.S. Citizens
summary: Republican and Democratic lawmakers suggest sanctions, more cooperation for Mexican forces to pursue gangs through busts and arrests. MEXICO CITY-U.S. pressure is rising on Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador to tackle the growing power of drug cartels after this week's massacre of nine U.S. citizens.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: IBM, BofA Team Up on Public Cloud Aimed at Banks
summary: Service is designed to meet the sector's regulatory and compliance requirements. Bank of America Corp. and International Business Machines Corp. have teamed up to develop a public-cloud computing service for banks, which have been reluctant to store customers' financial data outside their in-house systems.

title: Xerox Considers Bid to Acquire HP, Valued at $27 Billion
summary: Bid for HP would be at a premium to company's market value of $27 billion. Xerox Holdings Corp. has set its sights on a takeover of personal-computer and printer maker HP Inc., an audacious move that would unite two fading stars of technology.

title: Perry Wanted U.S. Energy Veterans on Naftogaz Board, Messages Say
summary: Text messages released by House impeachment investigators show exchanges between Trump administration officials. WASHINGTON-Energy Secretary Rick Perry wanted to put two U.S. energy industry veterans on the board of Ukraine's state-owned energy company, according to text messages written by the former Ukraine special envoy that differ with Mr. Perry's own account.

title: Firm Hired by Burisma Tried to Use Hunter Biden as Leverage
summary: Blue Star mentioned him to get State Department meetings and burnish image, emails indicate. WASHINGTON-A consulting firm hired by Burisma Group mentioned that former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden's son served on the Ukrainian gas company's board so the firm could leverage a meeting with the State Department, according to documents and a former U.S. official.

title: Proposed California Rule Threatens to Drive Out Plastics, Californians
summary: Texas is looking better all the time.. In ways large and small, California's "alternative universe" of overactive government has been making life more difficult for its citizens. In response, many of them are choosing not to be citizens. Expect more flight from the state that's leading the nation in electricity blackouts, unsheltered homelessness, and paper straw dissatisfaction.

title: AstraZeneca to Raise $1 Billion to Invest in China Startups
summary: New policy measures in Beijing have opened China to drug multinationals and helped Chinese biotechs attract investors. HONG KONG-AstraZeneca PLC plans to raise up to $1 billion for a new fund that would invest in Chinese health-care startups, making it the latest drug giant to place a bet on the world's second-largest pharmaceuticals market.

title: Ukraine Timeline: Frozen Aid, Calls for Election Probes, 'No Quid Pro Quo's'
summary: Sondland and Volker, witnesses in the House impeachment probe, provide a timeline of the summer's events in transcripts released Tuesday. House committees on Tuesday released the transcripts of testimony by Gordon Sondland, U.S. ambassador to the European Union, and Kurt Volker, former special envoy for Ukraine negotiations, who testified about their dealings with President Trump, his personal attorney, Rudy Giuliani, and others in the administration related to Ukraine.

title: Nine U.S. Citizens Killed in Highway Attack in Mexico
summary: Trump offers military help to combat drug cartels after massacre of women and children who were members of a Mormon community. MEXICO CITY-Gunmen in Mexico ambushed three SUVs carrying U.S. citizens, killing three women and six children, leading President Trump to call for a war on Mexican drug cartels and ramping up pressure on Mexico's leader to counter record levels of violence.

title: Affordable Rents at the iPad
summary: Apple offers $2.5 billion to help a housing crunch created by bad policy.. Silicon Valley wants to solve California's housing crunch. Apple pledged Monday to put $2.5 billion toward addressing the "availability and affordability crisis." The effort will include "mortgage assistance" for new home-buyers, and Apple will make available for housing development about $300 million of land it owns in San Jose.

title: Warren Is 70. Biden Is 76. Sanders Is 78. So What?
summary: Students debate the relevance of leading presidential candidates' advanced age.. Editor's note: This Future View is about the advanced age of leading U.S. presidential candidates. Next week we'll ask, "Is it fair for male-to-female transgender athletes to compete in women's sports? Is it fair to exclude them?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Nov. 12. The best responses will be published that night.

title: Regulatory Mop Up at the Court
summary: The Justices consider an illegal expansion of the Clean Water Act.. The Supreme Court Wednesday will consider in Maui v. Hawaii Wildlife Fund whether groundwater is a "navigable water." Ridiculous as this question may seem, the case reveals the ambitions of liberals who want to use water as a regulatory phalanx.

title: Vale Withheld Information From Regulator Before Brazil Dam Disaster
summary: Brazil's mining regulator said in a report that it relies on companies to divulge crucial information that helps it prioritize dam inspections. SÃO PAULO-Brazil's mining regulator said Vale SA withheld information from government inspectors about problems at its dam that collapsed in January, killing 270 people.

title: Sweet Cheeses! The Milk Road to China Is Driving Dairy Prices Higher
summary: Once wary of dairy, the country is relying on purchases from abroad to meet rising consumer demand. Milk prices are climbing around the globe and have reached multiyear highs, driven in part by a surprising surge in demand from China.

title: Russia Steps Up Efforts to Shield Hackers From Extradition to U.S.
summary: Kremlin resorts to prisoner swaps and coercion to keep potential cyber operatives out of U.S. hands, experts say. Naama Issachar trod a path familiar to many Israelis after completing her army service-she spent a few months traveling around India and planned to return to Tel Aviv in April, flying through Moscow because the airfare was cheaper.

title: New McDonald's CEO Takes Charge of Strategy He Helped Craft
summary: Chris Kempczinski, or 'Chris K' as employees call him, worked at PepsiCo and Kraft before the burger giant. McDonald's Corp.'s new chief executive is taking full responsibility for the plan he helped design for the company to upgrade its restaurants and lure in more diners.
